Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative:Development of a Hydrogen Discriminating Low Temperature 1-D Nanocomposite Micro-Sensor

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Project Abstract

The objective of this collaborative proposal is to realize fast, sensitive and discriminating detection of hydrogen detection at room temperature using a novel nanomaterial integrated microsensor. The approach is based on one dimensional porous nanostructures and array architectures of conducting oxides. The nanostructures will be prepared by sol-gel processing, electrospinning and fast laser induced self-organization while the sensor platform will be prepared by lithographic approaches.
The intellectual merit of this work will come from the application of fundamental scientific and engineering principles of nanofabrication, materials chemistry and electronics to novel sensor design. Specifically, understanding the relationships between one dimensional nanostructure, its architecture, oxide chemistry, and electronic response will permit a quantitative basis for design and fabrication of fast and sensitive metal oxide semiconductor sensors at the nanoscale.
The broader impact will come from cutting-edge interdisciplinary research and education activities in science and engineering across two institutions and neighboring schools involving underrepresented undergraduates, graduates and K-12 students/teachers. This project will ensure training of next-generation scientists and engineers in the areas of critical national need. The training and educational programs will equip the students with knowledge and skills for the integrated use of bottom-up nanomaterial synthesis and top-down device design approaches. Considering the recent public awareness on the need of clean alternative energy, the NSF support for this hydrogen sensor research provide a novel scientific and engineering springboard for the cost-effective design and fabrication of such sensors, that are crucial for storage, transportation, and distribution of hydrogen as an energy source.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research endeavor was
to develop a highly sensitive, selective and robust hydrogen gas detector that
operates at room temperature. In the early year of this project we tailored the
properties of SnO2 thin film to work as a hydrogen sensor. To
further tailor the sensor characteristics of SnO2, we researched
nano-sized array like structures. Nano-architectured SnO2 arrays
were designed with the use of nanosecond pulse laser interference irradiation
of the SnO2 thin films deposited on SiO2/Si substrates
using pulse laser deposition (PLD). In comparison to SnO2 thin film,
the SnO2 nanostructured array illustrates a significantly larger and
faster electrical response (~150 fold increase in Rhydrogen/RAir)
to minimal concentrations of hydrogen (as low as 300 ppm). Observing the
benefit of structural morphology, additional metal oxide semiconductors were
tested for potential hydrogen sensors. High aspect ratio 3-D carbon post
microarray were fabricated and conformally coated with ZnO using atomic layer
deposition (ALD). The ZnO coated on surface modified 3-D carbon post exhibited
encouraging results towards sensing hydrogen gas at low concentrations and will
be persued in the future. The project further trained undergraduates, graduate students and scientists. The results are disseminated in journal papers, presentations and patents. Students won various awards in national and international conferences. Further a RET is trained in this project and created modules in high school classroom. RET co-authored a paper from the RET supplement. Also undergraduate student co-authored a no of papers published in peer reviewed journals.


Last Modified: 06/02/2014
Modified by: Sudipta Seal
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Our research endeavor was to develop a highly sensitive, selective and robust hydrogen gas detector that operates at room temperature. In the early year of this project we tailored the properties of SnO2 thin film to work as a hydrogen sensor. To further tailor the sensor characteristics of SnO2, we researched nano-sized array like structures. Nano-architectured SnO2 arrays were designed with the use of nanosecond pulse laser interference irradiation of the SnO2 thin films deposited on SiO2/Si substrates using pulse laser deposition (PLD). In comparison to SnO2 thin film, the SnO2 nanostructured array illustrates a significantly larger and faster electrical response (~150 fold increase in Rhydrogen/RAir) to minimal concentrations of hydrogen (as low as 300 ppm). Observing the benefit of structural morphology, additional metal oxide semiconductors were tested for potential hydrogen sensors. High aspect ratio 3-D carbon post microarray were fabricated and conformally coated with ZnO using atomic layer deposition (ALD). The ZnO coated on surface modified 3-D carbon post exhibited encouraging results towards sensing hydrogen gas at low concentrations and will be persued in the future. The project further trained undergraduates, graduate students and scientists. The results are disseminated in journal papers, presentations and patents. Students won various awards in national and international conferences. Further a RET is trained in this project and created modules in high school classroom. RET co-authored a paper from the RET supplement. Also undergraduate student co-authored a no of papers published in peer reviewed journals. Last Modified: 06/02/2014 Submitted by: Sudipta Seal
